with potential synergies between climate objectives, health and equity
benefits, risks and implementation opportunities and barriers
(FLW) refer to the edible parts of plants and animals produced for human consumption that are not
Food loss occurs through spoilage, spilling or othe
consequences due to limitations in agricultural infrastructure, storage and packaging
Food waste typically takes place at the distribution (retail and food service) and consumption stages in
the food supply chain and refers to food appropriate for human consumption that is discarded or left to
. Options that could reduce FLW include: investing in harvesting and post
untries, taxing and other incentives to reduce business and consumer
level waste in developed countries, mandatory FLW reporting and reduction targets for large food
regulation of unfair trading practices, and active marketing of cosmetically i
(van Giesen and de Hooge 2019; Sinclair Taylor et al. 2019)
provision) that cause dietary and consumption changes and motivate consumers to actively make
decisions that reduce FLW. Reductions of FLW along the food chain bring a range of benefits beyond
mental stress (e.g. water and land competition, land
degradation, desertification), safeguarding food security, and reducing poverty
Additionally, FLW reduction is crucial for achieving SDG 12 which calls for
able consumption and production patterns’ through lowering per capita global food
waste by 50% at the retail and consumer level and reducing food losses along food supply chains by
2030. In line with these SDG targets, it is estimated that reducing FLW can
). The interlinkages between reducing FLW and food system sustainability are
discussed in Chapter 12. Recent literature identifies a range of barriers to climate change mitigation
which are linked to technological, biophysical, socio
cultural contexts at regional and local levels
(Blok et al. 2020; Vogel and Meyer 2018; Gromko and
. Examples of these barriers include inf
capacity limitations, institutional regulations, financial resources, constraining resources (e.g. energy),
information gaps (e.g. with retailers), and consumers’ behaviour

could substantially lower emissions, with estimated mitigation potential of 0.6
. In the SRCCL, the technical mitigation potential of reducing food
Developments since AR5 and IPCC Special Reports (SR1.5, SROC
SRCCL, there have been very few quantitative estimates of the mitigation potential of FLW reductions.
Evidence suggests that reducing FLW together with overall food intake could have substantial
sectoral studies indicate that reducing FLW in the EU can reduce emissions by 186 MtCO
equivalent of around 15% of the environmental impacts (climate, acidification, and eutrophication) of
